chapter.title: Using the Command Line Client

abstract.para: Many developers who want to maintain multiple packages do not like graphical frontends. The reasons for this range from uncomfortable mouse handling to the need to work on systems remotely, which is often easier to accomplish on a shell. To make this comfort also available to the &bs;, a command line client, osc was developed.

chapter.para: All actions on the &bs; require an authentication of the user. The &bs; uses the same account that is also used on the OpenSUSE wiki, found at . If you do not yet have an account, create on on this page.

The command line utility osc is available in the &bs;. To install this utility, add the catalog http://software.opensuse.org/download/openSUSE:/Tools/<product> to your installation sources where product is the installed operating system version. osc will then be available in your preferred installer.

When using the osc command for the first time, you will be prompted for your username and password. This is then stored in a file that is only readable by the current user, and is found at ${HOME}/.oscrc.

One of the first tasks is, to get a working copy of the home project of your user. To do this, change your working directory into a directory where you want to keep all the &bs; projects. Then run the command osc co home:<username>. The first time you do this, you will probably get only an empty directory. However, if you already used the web interface as described in , you will also get all existing packages of your home project.
